   PO4:4.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   yesterday highly suggestive of ARDS given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also
   includes post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in
   correct time frame per Heme-Onc; received
   1. Altered Mental Status
   Etiology of his altered mental status is likely multifactorial related
   to his gram negative rod bacteremia and hypercarbia related to
   parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia. Encephalitis or
   meningitis are also possible. Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]
   and had only 1 WBCs, although this is difficult to interpret in the
   setting of neutropenia. His glucose and total protein were normal,
   which is somewhat reassuring. Additional infection is also possible,
   although cultures remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia
   has been relatively chronic during this admission and is likely not a
   large contributor to his altered mental status.
   - will start treatmement for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   desensitization protocol (see below)
   - will start noninvasive ventilation for increased ventilation to
   improve his hypercarbia with intubation as needed
   - follow-up CSF Cultures
   - follow-up CSF studies - Toxoplasma gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and
   Coccidiodes
   - avoid further psychotropic medications
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. E. coli Bacteremia and UTI
   Patient had ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**], although subsequent urine
   cultures were negative after treatment with aztreonam. Surprisingly
   then his blood cultures returned with ESBL bacteremia on [**2165-3-15**],
   despite clearing of his urinary tract infection. He has been on
   aztreonam and gentamicin for treatment of this, although meropenem
   would be preferred in this patient due to inferiority of gentamicin in
   neutropenic patients. Patient unfortunately has anaphylaxis reaction to
   penicillins in the past and will need meropenem desensitiziation
   protocol for this.
   - discontinue gentamicin
   - continue vancomycin for broad gram positive coverage in this patient
   with febrile neutropenia, will follow-up with BMT regarding peeling
   this back given no gram positive infection to date and cultures NGTD
   - will follow-up with BMT team regarding need for micafungin
   - allergy consultation
   - start meropenem desensitization protocol once respiratory status is
   improved
   - will need tunneled catheter removed by interventional radiology once
   patient is stable from a respiratory standpoint and has received first
   dose of meropenem
   - daily blood cultures
   - appreciate ID input
   3. Hypoxia and Hypercarbia
   Patient is both hypoxic and hypercarbic, likely due to parainfluenza
   infection and obstructive sleep apnea.
   - will try noninvasive ventilation to improve oxygenation and
   ventilation; if no improvement will need to intubate
   4. Myeloma
   Patient is now day + 9 for SCT for multiple myeloma.
   - appreciate BMT recs
   - continue acyclovir, clotrimazole, and bactrim prophylaxis
   - continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   - continue immunosuppression with cyclosporine and mycophenolate
   mofetil
   5. Hyponatremia
   Etiology is most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia.
   - continue to monitor daily sodium
   - continue free water restriction
   - continue salt tabs
   6. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
   Patient with difficult to control blood glucose in the setting of
   infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   - appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   - continue insulin sliding scale with lantus
   7. Hypertension
   Patient has a history of hypertension in the past requiring Metoprolol
   Succinate 50mg PO bid and amlodipine 2.5mg PO daily. Currently
   normotensive
   - hold Toprol XL and amlodipine in the setting of gram negative rod
   bacteremia and will restart if BP increases
   8. Depression
   Patient has a history of major depression with significant medication
   requirements.
   - appreciate psychiatry input
   - continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
   9. Glaucoma
   Stable
   - continue timolol eye drops
   10. Hyperlipidemia
   Stable
   - hold atorvastatin in the acute setting
   11. Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain
   Stable
   - continue gapabentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone prn
   12. GERD
   Stable
   - continue PPI
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO for now pending improvement in respiratory status
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Tunneled (Hickman) Line - [**2165-3-17**] 12:15 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2165-3-17**] 12:15 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-3-18**] 02:03 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: Family meeting held  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma and was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

The patient's condition is rapidly deteriorating, with worsening bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, suggesting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is also experiencing hypercarbia, which is likely related to parainfluenza infection and obstructive sleep apnea.

The patient has a complex medical history, including type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). He has also had an anaphylactic reaction to penicillins in the past.

The patient's current medications include:

* Cyclosporine
* Mycophenolate mofetil
* Acyclovir
* Clotrimazole
* Bactrim
* Ursodiol
* Lantus
* Insulin sliding scale
* Duloxetine
* Lorazepam
* Timolol eye drops
* Atorvastatin (held)
* Gabapentin
* Oxycontin
* Oxycodone
* PPI

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F)
* Heart rate: 97 bpm
* Blood pressure: 98/57 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths/min
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* SpO2: 98%

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count: 5.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 19 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Total bilirubin: 1.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 127 mg/dL
* Sodium: 24 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.2 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory distress: ARDS, hypercarbia, and obstructive sleep apnea
* E. coli bacteremia: ESBL E. coli UTI, anaphylactic reaction to penicillins
* Hyponatremia: SIADH, secondary to pain and/or pneumonia
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus: difficult to control blood glucose in the setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids
* Hypertension: history of hypertension, currently normotensive
* Depression: history of major depression with significant medication requirements
* Glaucoma: stable
* Hyperlipidemia: stable
* Peripheral neuropathy and pain: stable
* GERD: stable

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Meropenem desensitization protocol for ESBL E. coli bacteremia
* Noninvasive ventilation for increased ventilation to improve hypercarbia
* Intubation as needed
* Follow-up CSF cultures
* Follow-up CSF studies - Toxoplasma gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidiodes
* Avoid further psychotropic medications
* Follow-up blood and urine cultures
* Discontinue gentamicin
* Continue vancomycin for broad gram-positive coverage
* Start micafungin if necessary
* Remove tunneled catheter once patient is stable from a respiratory standpoint and has received first dose of meropenem
* Daily blood cultures
* Continue immunosuppression with cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil
* Continue acyclovir, clotrimazole, and bactrim prophylaxis
* Continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
* Continue insulin sliding scale with lantus
* Hold Toprol XL and amlodipine in the setting of gram-negative rod bacteremia and will restart if BP increases
* Continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
* Continue timolol eye drops
* Hold atorvastatin in the acute setting
* Continue gabapentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone prn
* Continue PPI

   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   1. Altered Mental Status
   Etiology of his altered mental status is likely multifactorial related
   to his gram negative rod bacteremia and hypercarbia related to
   parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia. Encephalitis or
   meningitis are also possible. Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]
   and had only 1 WBCs, although this is difficult to interpret in the
   setting of neutropenia. His glucose and total protein were normal,
   which is somewhat reassuring. Additional infection is also possible,
   although cultures remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia
   has been relatively chronic during this admission and is likely not a
   large contributor to his altered mental status.
   - will start treatmement for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   desensitization protocol (see below)
   - will start noninvasive ventilation for increased ventilation to
   improve his hypercarbia with intubation as needed
   - follow-up CSF Cultures
   - follow-up CSF studies - Toxoplasma gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and
   Coccidiodes
   - avoid further psychotropic medications
   - follow-up blood and urine cultures
   2. E. coli Bacteremia and UTI
   Patient had ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**], although subsequent urine
   cultures were negative after treatment with aztreonam. Surprisingly
   then his blood cultures returned with ESBL bacteremia on [**2165-3-15**],
   despite clearing of his urinary tract infection. He has been on
   aztreonam and gentamicin for treatment of this, although meropenem
   would be preferred in this patient due to inferiority of gentamicin in
   neutropenic patients. Patient unfortunately has anaphylaxis reaction to
   penicillins in the past and will need meropenem desensitiziation
   protocol for this.
   - discontinue gentamicin
   - continue vancomycin for broad gram positive coverage in this patient
   with febrile neutropenia, will follow-up with BMT regarding peeling
   this back given no gram positive infection to date and cultures NGTD
   - will follow-up with BMT team regarding need for micafungin
   - allergy consultation
   - start meropenem desensitization protocol once respiratory status is
   improved
   - will need tunneled catheter removed by interventional radiology once
   patient is stable from a respiratory standpoint and has received first
   dose of meropenem
   - daily blood cultures
   - appreciate ID input
   3. Hypoxia and Hypercarbia
   Patient is both hypoxic and hypercarbic, likely due to parainfluenza
   infection and obstructive sleep apnea.
   - will try noninvasive ventilation to improve oxygenation and
   ventilation; if no improvement will need to intubate
   4. Myeloma
   Patient is now day + 9 for SCT for multiple myeloma.
   - appreciate BMT recs
   - continue acyclovir, clotrimazole, and bactrim prophylaxis
   - continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   - continue immunosuppression with cyclosporine and mycophenolate
   mofetil
   5. Hyponatremia
   Etiology is most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia.
   - continue to monitor daily sodium
   - continue free water restriction
   - continue salt tabs
   6. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
   Patient with difficult to control blood glucose in the setting of
   infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   - appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   - continue insulin sliding scale with lantus
   7. Hypertension
   Patient has a history of hypertension in the past requiring Metoprolol
   Succinate 50mg PO bid and amlodipine 2.5mg PO daily. Currently
   normotensive
   - hold Toprol XL and amlodipine in the setting of gram negative rod
   bacteremia and will restart if BP increases
   8. Depression
   Patient has a history of major depression with significant medication
   requirements.
   - appreciate psychiatry input
   - continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
   9. Glaucoma
   Stable
   - continue timolol eye drops
   10. Hyperlipidemia
   Stable
   - hold atorvastatin in the acute setting
   11. Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain
   Stable
   - continue gapabentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone prn
   12. GERD
   Stable
   - continue PPI

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma 9 days ago. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has a complex medical history, including multiple allergies, hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered mental status: likely multifactorial, related to gram-negative rod bacteremia, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia
* Hypoxia: likely due to parainfluenza infection and obstructive sleep apnea
* Hypercarbia: likely due to parainfluenza infection and obstructive sleep apnea
* E. coli bacteremia: treated with aztreonam and gentamicin, but patient has anaphylaxis reaction to penicillins and will require meropenem desensitization
* UTI: patient had ESBL E. coli UTI on February 26, but subsequent urine cultures were negative after treatment with aztreonam
* Hyponatremia: likely due to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or pneumonia
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus: patient has difficult-to-control blood glucose in the setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids
* Hypertension: patient has a history of hypertension, but currently normotensive
* Depression: patient has a history of major depression with significant medication requirements

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to hypercarbia and hypoxia
* Sepsis: patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to gram-negative rod bacteremia and UTI
* Renal failure: patient is at risk for renal failure due to sepsis and dehydration
* Hepatic failure: patient is at risk for hepatic failure due to sepsis and hypoxia
* Neurological complications: patient is at risk for neurological complications due to altered mental status, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia
* Gastrointestinal complications: patient is at risk for gastrointestinal complications due to hypercarbia, hypoxia, and sepsis
* Cardiovascular complications: patient is at risk for cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, hypoxia, and sepsis

Assessment and plan:

* Start treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem desensitization protocol
* Start noninvasive ventilation to improve oxygenation and ventilation
* Follow-up CSF cultures and studies
* Avoid further psychotropic medications
* Follow-up blood and urine cultures
* Discontinue gentamicin and continue vancomycin for broad gram-positive coverage
* Continue acyclovir, clotrimazole, and bactrim prophylaxis
* Continue immunosuppression with cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil
* Monitor daily sodium and continue free water restriction and salt tabs
* Continue insulin sliding scale with lantus
* Hold Toprol XL and amlodipine in the setting of gram-negative rod bacteremia and will restart if BP increases
* Continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
* Continue timolol eye drops
* Hold atorvastatin in the acute setting
* Continue gabapentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone prn
* Continue PPI

   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and

   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to his gram

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with multiple myeloma who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) on day +9. He was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, with bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, suggesting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's mental status is altered, likely due to a combination of factors including gram-negative rod bacteremia, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, and GERD.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 5.1
* Hct: 25.7
* Plt: 19
* Cr: 0.8
* TCO2: 33
* Glucose: 127
* ALT/AST: 17/53
* Alk Phos/T Bili: 63/0.8
* Differential-Neuts: 68.0%
* Band: 6.0%
* Lymph: 10.0%
* Mono: 14.0%
* Eos: 0.0%
* Lactic Acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Ca++: 8.1 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.6 mg/dL
* PO4: 4.2 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient's ARDS is worsening, and he requires mechanical ventilation.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, likely due to a combination of factors including gram-negative rod bacteremia, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia.
3. E. coli bacteremia and UTI: The patient has a history of ESBL E. coli UTI and bacteremia, which requires continued treatment with meropenem.
4. ARF: The patient has oliguric renal failure, which may be multifactorial and requires further evaluation and treatment.
5. Myeloma: The patient is at risk for complications related to his multiple myeloma, including engraftment syndrome and infections.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely related to SIADH, and he requires continued monitoring and treatment.
7. Type 2 diabetes mellitus: The patient's blood glucose levels are difficult to control, and he requires continued insulin sliding scale and lantus therapy.
8. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension, and his blood pressure is currently normal.
9. Depression: The patient has a history of depression, and he requires continued treatment with duloxetine and lorazepam.
10. Glaucoma: The patient has stable glaucoma, and he requires continued timolol eye drops.
11. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has stable hyperlipidemia, and he requires continued atorvastatin therapy.
12. Peripheral neuropathy and pain: The patient has stable peripheral neuropathy and pain, and he requires continued gabapentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone therapy.
13. GERD: The patient has stable GERD, and he requires continued PPI therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment with meropenem for E. coli bacteremia and UTI.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust mechanical ventilation as needed.
3. Continue treatment for ARF, including fluid boluses and renal consult.
4. Continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil and cyclosporine, and adjust as indicated.
5. Continue prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status closely and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Continue treatment for hyponatremia, including free water restriction and salt tabs.
8. Continue insulin sliding scale and lantus therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus.
9. Continue duloxetine and lorazepam therapy for depression.
10. Continue timolol eye drops for glaucoma.
11. Continue atorvastatin therapy for hyperlipidemia.
12. Continue gabapentin, oxycontin, and oxycodone therapy for peripheral neuropathy and pain.
13. Continue PPI therapy for GERD.

ICU care:

1. Nutrition: The patient is NPO for now, pending improvement in respiratory status, and will start on tube feeds.
2. Glycemic control: The patient is on regular insulin sliding scale.
3. Lines: The patient has a tunneled Hickman line, 20-gauge line, and arterial line.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is on boots for DVT, and stress ulcer and VAP prophylaxis.
5. Communication: A family meeting has been held, and the patient's code status is full code.
6. Disposition: The patient is currently in the ICU and will be discharged when his condition improves.

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with multiple myeloma (MM) who developed respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute renal failure while undergoing stem cell infusion. He has a history of anaphylactic reaction to penicillin and requires desensitization to meropenem. He was intubated for hypoxemic and hypercarbic respiratory failure and is currently receiving non-invasive ventilation (NIV) and invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV). He has bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and his partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) to fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) ratio is less than 200, consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He also has a positive blood culture for E. coli and a urine culture for E. coli with extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to the progression of ARDS and the need for continued mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen due to the presence of indwelling catheters and the limited antibiotic options. There is a risk of multi-organ failure and death.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen due to the presence of sepsis and the need for continued fluid resuscitation. There is a risk of chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing new infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection, due to the presence of indwelling catheters and the need for continued antibiotic therapy.
5. Bleeding: The patient is at risk of bleeding due to the need for continued anticoagulation therapy and the presence of indwelling catheters.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, due to the need for continued antibiotics and the presence of indwelling catheters.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient is at risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, due to the need for continued fluid resuscitation and the presence of indwelling catheters.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient is at risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures and stroke, due to the need for continued anticoagulation therapy and the presence of indwelling catheters.

   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   yesterday highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes
   post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in correct time
   frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc. [**Month (only) 51**] also have infectious
   process, including atypical, viral, PCP or even rapidly evolving
   bacterial pneumonia in immunosuppresed host. BAL viral screen positive
   for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen. Lastly, could represent DAH;
   less likely as sputum s/p intubation initially pink but cleared
   although certainly concern given thrombocytopenia.
   -mechanical vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -continue vanco and meropenem
   -cont micafungin
   -received high-dose solumedrol x 1, will f/u with Heme re: inclination
   to continue treating possible engraftment syndrome, keeping in mind
   that steroids may impair immune response to possible viral pneumonia.
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -follow-up blood and urine cultures, CSF cx and studies (Toxoplasma
   gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidiodes)
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -re-address with BMT and ID whether to remove lines
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oligric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential
   -follow-up renal recs
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Anemia: hematocrit 21.1 today (has been this low before although
   usually in mid 20s).
   -recheck hct in PM
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +11 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probably acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil; f/u
   cyclosporine level and adjust as indicated
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable (128-131-129).
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -f/u with renal re: correction of hyponatremia as patient is currently
   anuric
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. Currently
   normotensive.
   -holding antihypertensives in setting of gram negative rod bacteremia
   and will restart when clinically improved
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with
   significant medication requirements.
   -appreciate psychiatry input
   -hold duloxetine for now
   -f/u with psychiatry re: stopping duloxetine versus starting another
   SSRI in its place
   # Glaucoma
   -continue timolol eye drops

   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

   that steroids may impair immune response to possible viral pneumonia.

   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) on day 0. He was admitted to the ICU on day 9 due to altered mental status, hypoxia, and suspected ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS. He also has a history of parainfluenza pneumonia and is at risk for post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Respiratory distress with ARDS
* Altered mental status likely due to infection and hypercarbia
* ESBL E. coli bacteremia with UTI
* Oliguric renal failure likely due to multifactorial causes, including hypotension, volume depletion, supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, and acyclovir
* Anemia with hematocrit 21.1
* Myeloma with ongoing immunosuppression
* Hyponatremia likely due to SIADH
* Type 2 diabetes mellitus with difficulty controlling blood glucose
* Hypertension, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, and GERD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and ARDS may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potential extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's ESBL E. coli bacteremia and UTI may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and increase the risk of mortality.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's oliguric renal failure may progress to acute kidney injury, requiring dialysis and potential renal replacement therapy.
4. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and ongoing immunosuppression may increase the risk of opportunistic infections, including fungal, viral, and bacterial infections.
5. Engraftment syndrome: The patient's ongoing immunosuppression and history of parainfluenza pneumonia may increase the risk of engraftment syndrome, which can cause fever, rash, and other systemic symptoms.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of GERD and ongoing immunosuppression may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's type 2 diabetes mellitus and difficulty controlling blood glucose may increase the risk of hyperglycemia, which can cause complications such as ketoacidosis and nonketotic hyperglycemic hyperosmolar syndrome.
8. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and ongoing immunosuppression may increase the risk of hypertension, which can cause cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction and stroke.
9. Depression: The patient's history of depression and ongoing immunosuppression may increase the risk of depression, which can affect the patient's quality of life and increase the risk of suicidal behavior.
10. Glaucoma: The patient's history of glaucoma and ongoing immunosuppression may increase the risk of glaucoma, which can cause vision loss and blindness.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's ESBL E. coli bacteremia and UTI with meropenem.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medication dosages as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin dosages as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust antihypertensive medications as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust sedation medications as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust antacid medications as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's immunosuppression and adjust medications as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's glaucoma and adjust treatment as needed.
10. Consider consulting with a psychiatrist to assess the patient's depression and develop a treatment plan.

   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   yesterday highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes
   post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in correct time
   frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc. [**Month (only) 51**] also have infectious
   process, including atypical, viral, PCP or even rapidly evolving
   bacterial pneumonia in immunosuppresed host. BAL viral screen positive
   for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen. Lastly, could represent DAH;
   less likely as sputum s/p intubation initially pink but cleared
   although certainly concern given thrombocytopenia.
   -mechanical vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -continue vanco and meropenem
   -cont micafungin
   -received high-dose solumedrol x 1, will f/u with Heme re: inclination
   to continue treating possible engraftment syndrome
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -follow-up blood and urine cultures, CSF cx and studies (Toxoplasma
   gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidiodes)
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -re-address with BMT and ID whether to remove lines
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oligric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential
   -follow-up renal recs
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +11 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probably acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -clotrimazole and bactrim prophylaxis per protocol
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil; f/u
   cyclosporine level and adjust as indicated
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable (128-131-129).
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -f/u with renal re: correction of hyponatremia as patient is currently
   anuric
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. Currently
   normotensive.
   -holding antihypertensives in setting of gram negative rod bacteremia
   and will restart when clinically improved
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with
   significant medication requirements.
   -appreciate psychiatry input
   -continue duloxetine and lorazepam PO/IV prn
   # Glaucoma
   -continue timolol eye drops
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -holding atorvastatin in acute setting
   # Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain
   -stopped neurontin per renal recs
   -continue oxycodone prn
   # GERD
   -continue lansoprazole
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: will start on tube feeds
   Glycemic Control: regular insulin sliding scale

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress, GNR bacteremia, and other complications.

The patient's respiratory status has worsened, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS, and a PaO2:FiO2 ratio <200. The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and the goal is to wean the patient off the ventilator.

The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and has undergone allogeneic stem cell transplantation. The patient is also experiencing altered mental status, likely multifactorial in nature, and is being treated for possible engraftment syndrome.

The patient has a history of E. coli bacteremia and UTI, and is currently being treated with meropenem. The patient's renal function is compromised, with oliguric renal failure, and the differential diagnosis includes acyclovir-induced nephrotoxicity.

The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, depression, glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy, and GERD, and is being managed accordingly.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate levels, and decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient is not weaned off the ventilator.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of GNR bacteremia and UTI, and there is a risk of sepsis if the infection is not adequately treated.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of acute kidney injury if the patient is not adequately hydrated and if the underlying cause of the kidney injury is not addressed.
4. Engraftment syndrome: The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and has undergone allogeneic stem cell transplantation, and there is a risk of engraftment syndrome if the patient's immune system is not adequately suppressed.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, and there is a risk of hyperglycemia if the patient's blood glucose levels are not adequately controlled.
6. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension, and there is a risk of hypertension if the patient's blood pressure is not adequately controlled.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of GNR bacteremia and UTI, and there is a risk of infection if the patient is not adequately treated.
8. Nephrotoxicity: The patient is at risk of nephrotoxicity if the patient is not adequately hydrated and if the underlying cause of the kidney injury is not addressed.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and the goal is to wean the patient off the ventilator.
2. Antibiotics: The patient is being treated with meropenem for GNR bacteremia and UTI.
3. Renal replacement therapy: The patient may require renal replacement therapy if the patient's renal function does not improve.
4. Fluid management: The patient's fluid management is critical, and the patient must be adequately hydrated to prevent kidney injury.
5. Blood glucose management: The patient's blood glucose levels must be adequately controlled to prevent hyperglycemia.
6. Blood pressure management: The patient's blood pressure must be adequately controlled to prevent hypertension.
7. Infection control: The patient must be adequately treated for GNR bacteremia and UTI to prevent infection.
8. Nephrotoxicity prevention: The patient must be adequately hydrated and the underlying cause of the kidney injury must be addressed to prevent nephrotoxicity.

   into alveolar space.

he has had reasonable optimization of PEEP

   with minimal change day to day.  Peak inspiratory pressures in the
   range of 24 are quite reasonable and should be well tolerated.

   may well be just below lower inflection point of compliance curve.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male admitted with sepsis and respiratory failure with ARDS. The patient has been diagnosed with Para-influenza 3 on BAL specimen and has blood alveolar secretions without progressive bleeding, suggesting diffuse alveolar damage and RBC leakage into the alveolar space.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. ARDS/Respiratory Failure: The patient has had reasonable optimization of PEEP and ventilatory support with lung-protective strategies. However, the patient may still be below the lower inflection point of the compliance curve, and PEEP up-titration to 12 may be necessary.
2. Renal Failure, Acute (ARF): The patient has profound impairment in renal function, is anuric, and has been experiencing hypotension, medication effects, contrast effects, and sepsis. CVVH may be necessary for volume removal if oxygenation becomes difficult.
3. Sepsis: The patient has GNR bacteremia, which is convincingly the dominant insult. Meropenem will be continued, and IVF as needed will be provided. Blood cultures will be repeated today to ensure infection control.
4. Multiple Myeloma (Cancer, Malignant Neoplasm): The patient has undergone bone marrow transplantation (BMT) and is receiving ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may experience worsening respiratory failure, leading to further compromise of lung function and potentially life-threatening hypoxia.
2. Renal failure: The patient's anuria and profound impairment in renal function may lead to further deterioration in renal function, potentially requiring dialysis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's GNR bacteremia may lead to further sepsis, potentially causing organ failure and death.
4. ARDS: The patient's diffuse alveolar damage and RBC leakage into the alveolar space may lead to further worsening of ARDS, potentially causing life-threatening hypoxia.
5. Infection control: The patient's GNR bacteremia may lead to further infection, potentially causing sepsis and organ failure.

The patient's medication list includes several antibiotics and other medications that may be contributing to the patient's condition. Further monitoring and management of the patient's condition are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   61yo male now Day +9 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma transferred
   to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and
   meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   yesterday highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes
   post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in correct time
   frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc. [**Month (only) 51**] also have infectious
   process, including atypical, viral, PCP or even rapidly evolving
   bacterial pneumonia in immunosuppresed host. BAL viral screen positive
   for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen. Lastly, could represent DAH;
   less likely as sputum s/p intubation initially pink but cleared
   although certainly concern given thrombocytopenia.
   -mechanical vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -continue vanco and meropenem
   -cont micafungin
   -received high-dose solumedrol x 1, trying to avoid steroids in setting
   of possible viral pneumonia
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -follow-up blood and urine cultures, CSF cx and studies (Toxoplasma
   gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidiodes)
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oligric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential
   -follow-up renal recs
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Anemia: hematocrit 25, up from 20 after 1U PRBCs- appropriate bump
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +12 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probable acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil; f/u
   cyclosporine level and adjust as indicated
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable.
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -f/u with renal re: correction of hyponatremia as patient is currently
   anuric
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus,
 dose as patient is NPO
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. Currently
   normotensive.
   -holding antihypertensives in setting of gram negative rod bacteremia
   and will restart when clinically improved
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with

   -appreciate psychiatry input

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma. He was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has developed respiratory distress, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS, and is requiring mechanical ventilation. He also has altered mental status, likely multifactorial, and is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is deteriorating, and he is at risk for further complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of ESBL E. coli bacteremia and is at risk for further septic episodes.
3. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient has oliguric renal failure, and his creatinine levels are increasing. He is at risk for further ARF, particularly if his underlying conditions, such as hypotension and volume depletion, are not addressed.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and is at risk for hyperglycemia, particularly in the setting of infection and steroid use.
5. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is at risk for further hypertension, particularly in the setting of infection and medication use.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, likely related to SIADH, and is at risk for further complications, including seizures and coma.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of infections, including ESBL E. coli bacteremia, and is at risk for further infections, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding, particularly in the setting of infection and medication use.

Recommendations:

1. Continue meropenem and vancomycin for treatment of ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider adjusting his ventilator settings as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if his creatinine levels continue to increase.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust his insulin regimen as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and consider restarting antihypertensives when clinically improved.
6. Monitor the patient's sodium levels closely and consider adjusting his fluid management plan as needed.
7. Consider starting TPN as the patient is not tolerating tube feeds.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and consider adjusting his medication regimen as needed.

These recommendations are based on the patient's medical history, laboratory results, and current clinical status. Further evaluation and management will depend on the patient's response to treatment and the development of any new complications.

   -follow-up blood and urine cultures, CSF cx and studies (Toxoplasma
   gondii, EBV PCR, HHV 6, HSV, and Coccidiodes)
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oligric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential.
   -follow-up renal recs
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Anemia: hematocrit 25, up from 20 after 1U PRBCs- appropriate bump
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +12 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probable acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil; f/u
   cyclosporine level and adjust as indicated
   -avoiding steroids if possible d/t viral pneumonia
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable.
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -f/u with renal re: correction of hyponatremia as patient is currently
   anuric
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the
   setting of infection, underlying diabetes mellitus, and steroids.
   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input
   -continue humalog sliding scale with Lantus,
 dose as patient is NPO
   # Hypertension: Patient has a history of hypertension in the past
   requiring metoprolol 50 [**Hospital1 **] and amlodipine 2.5 qday. Currently
   normotensive.
   -holding antihypertensives in setting of gram negative rod bacteremia
   and will restart when clinically improved
   # Depression: Patient has a history of major depression with
   significant medication requirements.
   -appreciate psychiatry input
   -hold duloxetine for now
   # Glaucoma
   -continue timolol eye drops
   # Hyperlipidemia
   -holding atorvastatin in acute setting
   # Peripheral Neuropathy and Pain
   -stopped neurontin per renal recs
   # GERD
   -continue lansoprazole
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: consider starting TPN if continues to have high residuals
   with tube feeds; will continue Reglan 5 mg tid
   Glycemic Control: humalog insulin sliding scale with Lantus

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He is a day +12 post-allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma. The patient's respiratory status has rapidly deteriorated, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of ARDS. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a goal Vt of 4 mL/kg IBW per ARDS protocol. The patient's altered mental status is likely multifactorial, related to infection, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia. He has a history of anaphylaxis to penicillins and is being treated with meropenem for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is rapidly deteriorating, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a severe infection with ESBL E. coli bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient has oliguric renal failure, which may be related to multiple factors, including hypotension, volume depletion, and supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has chronic hyponatremia, which may be related to SIADH, and is at risk of developing seizures or other complications.
5. Infection-related complications: The patient has a history of anaphylaxis to penicillins and is being treated with meropenem, which may lead to allergic reactions or other complications.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding, and his platelet count is low, which may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase his risk of bleeding.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and is at risk of developing hyperglycemia, which can lead to complications such as ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Continue to treat the patient's ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem and monitor his response to treatment.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management and medication dosing accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his fluid management and medication dosing accordingly.
5. Consider repeating the patient's CXR to evaluate for any changes in his lung infiltrates.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his sedation and pain management accordingly.
7. Consider performing a lumbar puncture to evaluate for any signs of meningitis or other central nervous system complications.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust his insulin dosing accordingly.
9. Consider starting the patient on TPN if he continues to have high residuals with tube feeds.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust his platelet transfusions accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, ARDS, and acute renal failure. He has a history of multiple myeloma, type II diabetes, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 107 bpm, and blood pressure of 119/70 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97% on 45% FiO2. His hemodynamic monitoring shows a cardiac index of 2.5 L/min/m2 and a systemic vascular resistance of 1,200 dyne/s/cm5.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate levels, indicating ongoing inflammation and organ dysfunction. His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 4.7 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 51 mg/dL. His liver function tests are normal, but his alkaline phosphatase level is elevated.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a compliance of 47.8 cmH2O/mL and a plateau pressure of 21 cmH2O. His arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.33, partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 44 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen of 90 mmHg.

The patient's medical history is significant for multiple myeloma, type II diabetes, and acute respiratory distress syndrome. He has a history of allergies to penicillins, morphine, and Dilaudid-Hp. He is currently receiving antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals for his sepsis and ARDS.

The patient's plan of care includes continued mechanical ventilation with a target PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 45%. He will be weaned off sedation and will be evaluated for extubation. His sepsis will be managed with antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals, and his renal failure will be managed with hemodialysis and medication adjustments.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for more aggressive respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease and the need for dialysis.
4. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may increase his risk of infection, particularly with fungal or viral pathogens.
5. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures or trauma.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac index is low, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular instability and the need for cardiac support.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

   61yo male now Day +13 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma
   transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status,
   hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   were highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes
   post-transplant reaction and engraftment syndrome as in correct time
   frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc.. BAL viral screen positive
   for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen.
   -mechanical vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -Continue to wean PEEP and try daily pressure support trials.
   -continue vanco and meropenem
   -continue micafungin
   -improvement in respiratory status will largely depend upon improving
   renal function, as well as tx of pneumonia as above
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -CSF studies negative to date. Continue to follow up other Cx data.
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem

   -daily blood cultures

   # ARF: Oligric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top

Summary:

The patient is a 61-year-old male who underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) for multiple myeloma 13 days ago. He was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He has developed respiratory distress, likely due to ARDS, and is being mechanically ventilated. He also has altered mental status, likely multifactorial, and is being treated for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He has oliguric renal failure, which is likely multifactorial, and is being treated with meropenem and micafungin. He has anemia and is being transfused with PRBCs. He has a history of multiple myeloma and is being treated with cyclosporine and mycophenolate mofetil.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to ARDS.
2. Sepsis: The patient has ESBL E. coli bacteremia and is at risk of developing sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has oliguric renal failure, which is likely multifactorial, and is at risk of developing AKI.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be related to SIADH or underlying kidney disease.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to underlying kidney disease or bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of multiple infections, including ESBL E. coli bacteremia and parainfluenza pneumonia, and is at risk of developing additional infections.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and is at risk of developing hyperglycemia.
8. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is at risk of developing hypertension due to decreased sedation and agitation.
9. Depression: The patient has a history of major depression and is at risk of developing depression.
10. Glaucoma: The patient has a history of glaucoma and is at risk of developing glaucoma due to decreased visual acuity.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem and micafungin.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medication dosing as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin dosing as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust medication dosing as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust sedation levels as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's visual acuity and adjust glaucoma treatment as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust fluid management as needed.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin dosing as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, sepsis, and multiple myeloma. The patient has shown significant improvement in respiratory failure, allowing for weaning of PEEP and transition to PSV. However, he still retains severe oliguria and worsening renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: Despite improvement in oxygenation, the patient's volume overload may hinder extubation. Weaning sedation, continuing antibiotics, and moving to CVVH to remove excess volume may be necessary.
2. Pneumonia: The patient is receiving Meropenem, and it is essential to monitor for signs of infection and adjust treatment as needed.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels continue to worsen, and near anuria is present. Moving to catheter placement may be necessary if diuretics do not show a brisk response.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is being managed with Atenolol, and TNG has been weaned off. Close monitoring of blood pressure and adjustment of medication as needed is crucial.
5. Volume overload: The patient's fluid balance data shows a significant amount of fluid intake, which may exacerbate his respiratory failure and oliguria. Monitoring of fluid intake and output is essential to prevent further volume overload.
6. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is being managed with antibiotics, and close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies is necessary to adjust treatment as needed.
7. Multiple Myeloma: The patient's underlying cancer may affect his response to treatment and increase the risk of complications.
8. Nutritional concerns: The patient is receiving Nutren Renal, and close monitoring of his nutritional status is essential to prevent malnutrition and related complications.
9. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose levels are being monitored, and adjustments to his insulin regimen may be necessary to maintain tight glycemic control.
10. Infection control: The patient is at risk for VAP, and strict infection control measures should be implemented to prevent the development of VAP.

It is essential to continue close monitoring of the patient's condition, adjust treatment as needed, and consider consulting with specialists to optimize his care.

   Assessment and Plan
   61 yo man now Day +14 of allogeneic SCT for multiple myeloma
   transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 1**] for evaluation of altered mental status,
   hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia.
   # Respiratory distress: Quickly evolving bilateral patchy infiltrates
   were highly suggestive of ARDS in setting of sepsis and known
   parainfluenza pneumonia given PaO2:FiO2 <200. Ddx also includes volume
   overload from renal failure, post-transplant reaction and engraftment
   syndrome as in correct time frame and given increased WBC per Heme-Onc.
   BAL viral screen positive for parainfluenza type 3 viral antigen,
   negative for PCP.
   [**Name10 (NameIs) 7416**] vent (goal Vt 4mg/kg IBW per ARDS protocol)
   -continue to wean PEEP and try daily pressure support trials;
   spontaneous breathing trial today
   -continue meropenem and vancomycin
   -continue micafungin
   -improvement in respiratory status will largely depend upon improving
   renal function, as well as tx of pneumonia as above
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to infection and
   hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, further worsened by hyponatremia.
   Lumbar puncture was performed on [**2165-3-15**]; 1 WBC difficult to interpret
   in the setting of neutropenia but nl glucose and total protein
   reassuring. Additional infection is also possible, although cultures
   remain NGTD for additional infection. Hyponatremia has been relatively
   chronic during this admission and is likely not a large contributor to
   his altered mental status.
   -continue treatment for ESBL E. coli bacteremia with meropenem
   -CSF studies negative to date. Continue to follow up other culture
   data.
   -appreciate psychiatry recs
   # E. coli Bacteremia and UTI: ESBL E. coli UTI on [**2165-2-26**] with
   subsequent clearance s/p aztreonam but [**3-15**] and [**3-16**] cx now with ESBL
   bacteremia. Had been on aztreonam and gentamicin, now switched to
   meropenem per ID recs s/p successful desensitization given h/o
   anaphylaxis on penicillins.
   -continue meropenem
   -will leave lines in for now, pending surveillance cultures
   -daily blood cultures
   -f/u allergy and ID recs
   # ARF: Oliguric renal failure. Likely multifactorial given hypotension
   in setting of intubation w/ increased lactate, volume depletion
   (?insensible losses), supratherapeutic cyclosporin levels, gentamicin,
   recent contrast load, and acyclovir. Urine sediment [**3-18**] with numerous
   crystals, believe acyclovir- thus acyclovir-related ARF is at the top
   of the differential.
   -continue CVVH per renal team
   -dose all meds for GFR <10
   # Anemia: hematocrit 20 decreased from 25 on [**2165-3-20**].
   -guiaic all stools
   -transfuse for <21
   # Myeloma: Patient is now day +14 of SCT for multiple myeloma.
   -Dose cyclosporine per level; goal around 200.
   -f/u BMT recs
   -holding acyclovir d/t probable acyclovir-related acute renal failure
   -nystatin for thrush prophylaxis
   -continue ursodiol per BMT protocol
   -continue immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil;
   -avoiding steroids if possible d/t viral pneumonia
   # Hyponatremia: Most likely related to SIADH, secondary to pain and/or
   pneumonia. Currently stable.
   -continue to monitor daily sodium
   -continue free water restriction
   -CVVH as above
   # Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Difficult to control blood glucose in the

   -appreciate [**Last Name (un) 303**] input

 dose as patient is NPO

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. The patient has a history of multiple myeloma and underwent allogeneic stem cell transplantation (SCT) 14 days prior to admission.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory distress: The patient has bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, which are highly suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in the setting of sepsis and known parainfluenza pneumonia.
* Altered mental status: The patient is likely experiencing multifactorial altered mental status due to infection, hypercarbia related to parainfluenza, and hyponatremia.
* E. coli bacteremia and UTI: The patient has ESBL E. coli bacteremia and UTI, which is being treated with meropenem.
* Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient has oliguric renal failure, which is likely multifactorial and possibly related to acyclovir-induced ARF.
* Anemia: The patient has a hematocrit of 20, which has decreased from 25 on the previous day.
* Myeloma: The patient is in the early stages of SCT for multiple myeloma and is receiving immunosuppressive therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Progressive respiratory failure due to ARDS
* Worsening of altered mental status due to infection, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia
* Development of septic shock due to E. coli bacteremia
* Further decline in renal function due to ARF
* Development of bleeding complications due to thrombocytopenia
* Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppressive therapy

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue meropenem for E. coli bacteremia and UTI
* Continue CVVH for ARF
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust treatment as necessary
* Continue immunosuppressive therapy for myeloma
* Monitor for signs of bleeding complications and adjust platelet transfusions as necessary
* Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotics as necessary
* Continue to monitor and manage respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall, 145 kg obese individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and undergoing meropenem desensitization. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), heart rate 114 bpm, blood pressure 156/70 mmHg, respiratory rate 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 95%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions. 

The patient has a right-sided portacath and a left-sided tunneled catheter over an erythematous patch, which may be an old radiation therapy site. The patient is unable to assess jugular venous distension due to their 12-17 obese habitus. 

Laboratory results show the following: white blood cell count 6.8 K/uL, hemoglobin 7.5 g/dL, platelet count 68 K/uL, creatinine 7.0 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen 120 mg/dL. 

The patient has been receiving meropenem, vancomycin, and micafungin, and has been transfused with one unit of packed red blood cells. The patient has a fever greater than 101°F and has been treated with hydrocortisone and ceftriaxone. 

The patient has a high risk of line infection, sinus infection, and deep vein thrombosis. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, a peak inspiratory pressure of 19 cmH2O, and a fraction of inspired oxygen of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.37, partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 34 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen of 99 mmHg. 

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's high fever, tachycardia, and respiratory distress suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Line infection: The patient's risk of line infection is high due to the presence of multiple central lines and the patient's immunocompromised state.
3. Sinus infection: The patient's fever and sinus tenderness suggest the possibility of sinus infection.
4. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis is high due to their immobility and the presence of central lines.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and need for mechanical ventilation suggest the possibility of respiratory failure.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and sinus tachycardia suggest the possibility of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
7. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels suggest the possibility of renal failure.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 61-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU for evaluation of altered mental status, hypoxia, and meropenem desensitization for ESBL E. coli bacteremia. He is currently day +14 of allogeneic stem cell transplantation for multiple myeloma.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in the setting of sepsis and known parainfluenza pneumonia. His PaO2:FiO2 ratio is <200, indicating severe hypoxia. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's mental status is altered, likely multifactorial in origin, with a possibility of infection, hypercarbia, and hyponatremia contributing factors. Lumbar puncture was performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies were negative. The patient is receiving meropenem for ESBL E. coli bacteremia and UTI, and his CSF studies are pending.

The patient has oliguric renal failure, likely multifactorial in origin, with a possibility of acyclovir-related acute renal failure. He is receiving continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) per renal team recommendation.

The patient has a history of anemia, with a hematocrit of 20, and is receiving guaiac all stools and transfusions for <21.

The patient's myeloma is being managed with cyclosporine, mycophenolate mofetil, and ursodiol per BMT protocol.

The patient has hyponatremia, likely related to SIADH, and is receiving free water restriction and CVVH.

The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is difficult to control in the setting of infection, underlying diabetes, and steroids. He is receiving humalog sliding scale with Lantus.

The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with metoprolol and amlodipine. He has a history of depression and is receiving psychiatric input.

The patient has a number of other medical conditions, including glaucoma, hyperlipidemia, peripheral neuropathy and pain, and GERD.

The patient's ICU care plan includes nutrition via total parenteral nutrition (TPN), glycemic control with insulin, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
